question_details.query: In an agricultural landscape, what are the effects of different habitat and farming management practices on bat populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Research shows that agricultural landscape management practices have varying effects on bat populations. Organic farming compared to conventional farming demonstrates mixed results: five of nine studies found no difference in overall bat activity, while four studies found higher activity on organic farms, including higher feeding activity and species-specific benefits for Brazilian free-tailed bats and Myotis species over water habitats (action 961). Field size matters, with one study finding higher activity for six of seven bat species in landscapes with smaller fields compared to larger fields (action 1939). Hedgerow management shows benefits when trimming is less frequent: hedges trimmed ≥3 years prior had more bat species and higher activity for two of eight species compared to recently trimmed hedges (action 1943). Creating tree plantations on agricultural land showed no difference in species richness, with two of three studies finding no difference in bat activity, though plantations next to remnant vegetation had higher activity than isolated plantations (action 958). Agri-environment schemes showed no significant benefits, with two of three studies finding no difference in overall bat activity compared to conventional farms, and one study finding lower activity on scheme farms (action 962). Creating artificial water sources such as farm ponds and reservoirs can increase bat activity compared to surrounding habitats (action 959). Riparian buffers showed no effect on pipistrelle activity in one study (action 2284). No significant difference was found for pipistrelle activity between species-rich grassland created on agri-environment scheme farms and conventional farm fields (action 2051).

question_details.query: What are the known benefits and negative impacts of providing artificial roosts for bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from 44 studies shows that bats do use artificial roosts (bat boxes) with 72 bat species documented using them, though only 18 species commonly use them and 31 species use them as maternity roosts (Action ID: 1024). Benefits include increased occupancy over time, with nine studies finding bat box use increased 2-10 times up to 10 years after installation (Action ID: 1024). However, there are significant limitations and negative impacts. Common pipistrelle bats used heated bat boxes at only one of seven sites, and none were used by maternity colonies (Action ID: 2052). Displaced bats often fail to use provided alternatives - two studies found bats displaced from buildings did not use any of 43 bat houses of four different designs or 12 heated bat boxes of one design (Action ID: 1024). When alternative roosts are created within developments, two studies found bats did not use any of the alternative roosts provided in bat houses or purpose-built bat walls after exclusion from buildings, and a UK review found new bat boxes/lofts built to replace destroyed roosts were four times less likely to be used by returning bats than roosts retained during development (Action ID: 949). Success rates vary considerably, with 22 studies finding bats occupying less than half of bat boxes provided (0-49%) while nine studies found bats occupying more than half (54-100%) (Action ID: 1024).

To reduce the impact of pollution on bats, what is the evidence for the effectiveness of changing effluent treatments versus reducing chemical use in agriculture?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence, there is no research evaluating the effectiveness of changing effluent treatments for reducing pollution impacts on bats. Action 1016 (Change effluent treatments used in agriculture and forestry) and action 2012 (Introduce or enforce legislation to prevent ponds and streams from being contaminated by toxins) both show "no studies" found, meaning no research has directly evaluated these interventions for bat populations.

In contrast, reducing chemical use in agriculture shows evidence of effectiveness for bat conservation. Action 2331 found that farms using few or no chemicals had different bat species compositions and higher overall bat activity than those using high chemical inputs. Action 2013, encompassing broader research on reducing pesticide, herbicide or fertiliser use, found that four studies across Mexico, Portugal, Germany and Columbia showed positive effects: farms with few or no chemical inputs had higher bat abundance and diversity than those with high chemical inputs, and bats in chemical-free areas had better body condition. Action 961 on organic farming found mixed results across twelve studies, with some showing higher bat activity on organic farms while others found no difference.
summary_statements: There is no research evaluating the effectiveness of changing effluent treatments for reducing pollution impacts on bats.

What actions can be taken during building developments to mitigate the disturbance and loss of bat roosts?

summary_details.relevant_summary: During building developments, several actions can be taken to mitigate disturbance and loss of bat roosts. Retaining existing bat roosts and access points within developments has shown positive results, with three studies finding that bats continued to use retained roosts after development, and retained roosts were more likely to be used than newly created ones (Action 947). Creating alternative bat roosts within developments has been attempted in eleven studies, with mixed results - while some bats used purpose-built roosts after original roosts were destroyed, new bat boxes/lofts were four times less likely to be used by returning bats than retained roosts (Action 949). Relocating access points to bat roosts within developments showed variable outcomes, with fewer bats using relocated access points in some cases (Action 946). Legal protection during development has been implemented, though one review found that 68% of roosts were still destroyed despite licensing requirements (Action 1935). Excluding bats from roosts during building work did not change roost switching frequency or foraging behavior of soprano pipistrelle colonies (Action 1930). No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of training for conservationists and developers (Action 997), educating homeowners about bat laws (Action 1931), installing sound barriers (Action 2023), or sound-proofing insulation (Action 1929).

What does the evidence say about mitigating noise and chemical pollution from timber treatments for bats within their roosts?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence for mitigating noise and chemical pollution from timber treatments for bats within their roosts is very limited. For chemical pollution mitigation, one replicated, controlled laboratory study in the UK found that treating timber with lindane and pentachlorophenol 14 months prior to bat exposure increased survival but did not prevent death (Action ID: 1023). However, no studies were found evaluating other proposed mitigation measures such as using mammal-safe timber treatments in roof spaces (Action ID: 1022), imposing noise limits near bat roosts (Action ID: 1021), installing sound-proofing insulation between bat roosts and human-occupied areas (Action ID: 1929), or installing sound barriers near bat roosts (Action ID: 2023). The lack of studies means the effectiveness of these potential mitigation measures remains unassessed.

question_details.query: Within agricultural landscapes, what is the evidence for the effectiveness of managing field boundaries and margins for bat conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence for managing field boundaries and margins for bat conservation in agricultural landscapes shows mixed results. One study found that retaining unmown field margins did not affect pipistrelle activity compared to conventional field margins (Action ID 1940). Another study showed that planting field margins with diverse plant species increased activity of soprano pipistrelles and barbastelle bats, though there was no effect on common pipistrelles (Action ID 1941). Research also found that maintaining smaller field sizes resulted in higher activity for six of seven bat species compared to landscapes with larger fields (Action ID 1939). While hedgerow management showed benefits for other mammals, specific evidence for bats was not found in the studies reviewed (Action ID 2383). No studies were found evaluating the effects of retaining existing in-field trees on bat populations (Action ID 1945).

question_details.query: To mitigate road impacts on bats, how effective are different purpose-built crossing structures like green bridges, overpasses, and gantries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, green bridges appear to be highly effective with one UK study finding 97% of bats used a green bridge (Action ID 979). Overpasses show mixed effectiveness - one overpass with planters was used by two-thirds of crossing bats, while an unvegetated overpass was not used at all (Action ID 977). Two studies across Ireland and France found that bat species used overpasses but up to three-quarters of bats still crossed at traffic height or at other nearby locations. Bat gantries/bat bridges show poor effectiveness - two UK studies found fewer bats used gantries than crossed roads at traffic height, with one gantry not used at all (Action ID 978). A French study similarly found that while a temporary gantry was used by three bat species, almost half of bats crossed at other locations. Additional data shows that underpasses are used by some bat species but bats continue to cross roads above them (Action ID 976).

question_details.query: What is the evidence for managing linear features like hedges and riparian buffers on farmland to benefit bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence for managing linear features like hedges and riparian buffers on farmland to benefit bats is limited and mixed. One replicated, paired sites study in the UK found that pipistrelle activity (relative abundance) did not differ along waterways with riparian buffers on agri-environment scheme farms compared to conventional farms (action ID 2284). Similarly, one replicated, paired sites study in the UK found that pipistrelle activity did not differ between hedges managed for wildlife on agri-environment scheme farms and hedges on conventional farms (action ID 1943). However, one replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that hedges trimmed ≥3 years prior had more bat species recorded along them than hedges trimmed during the previous winter, and higher activity of two of eight bat species/species groups (action ID 1943).
summary_statements: The evidence for managing linear features like hedges and riparian buffers on farmland to benefit bats is limited and mixed.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken in urban environments to create or protect foraging and roosting habitat for bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Urban environments can support bat populations through several habitat creation and protection measures. For foraging habitat, creating or restoring bat foraging habitat in urban areas has shown positive results, with studies finding greater bat activity over biodiversity green roofs compared to conventional unvegetated roofs (Action 954). Protecting brownfield or ex-industrial sites can also provide habitat, with one study recording five bat species within a protected urban wildlife refuge on an abandoned manufacturing site (Action 953). For roosting habitat, multiple approaches are available. Providing bat boxes has been extensively studied, with 41 of 43 studies finding that bats used bat boxes installed in various urban settings including buildings, bridges, and urban areas (Action 1024). Studies have found that 72 bat species used bat boxes across Europe, North America and Asia. Creating artificial hollows and cracks in trees can provide natural roosting opportunities, with one study finding that eight of 16 artificial hollows cut into trees were used by roosting long-eared bats (Action 2047). Retaining veteran and standing dead trees as natural roosting sites is also recommended, though this approach lacks direct study evidence (Action 993). Additional urban habitat protection measures include increasing semi-natural habitat within gardens (Action 1933) and protecting greenfield sites or undeveloped land in urban areas (Action 1934), though these actions also lack direct evaluation studies.

question_details.query: What are the most effective types of artificial roosts for bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the research evidence, several types of artificial roosts have been used by bats with varying success rates. Bat boxes have been studied most extensively across 44 studies, with 72 bat species using them worldwide, though only 18 species commonly used them and 31 species used them as maternity roosts. Black bat boxes were found to be used more than grey, white, or wooden boxes. Two-compartment bat boxes were preferred over single compartment designs during breeding season. Concrete bat boxes had higher occupancy rates than wooden ones. Rocket boxes were preferred by Indiana bats over conventional wooden bat boxes. Artificial caves and hibernacula created in the UK and Germany were used by up to four bat species, with one UK study showing bat usage increased over nine years. Artificial tree hollows and cracks carved into trees in Australia were used by long-eared bats, with eight of 16 hollows being occupied. Spaces created in road bridges and culverts in the USA successfully recolonized by bats in similar or greater numbers at four of eight sites. Bat box placement also affected effectiveness, with boxes on buildings showing higher occupancy than those on trees. However, some studies found displaced bats did not use provided bat boxes, and heated bat boxes showed limited success with common pipistrelles and Natterer's bats.

question_details.query: What design and placement factors are associated with higher occupancy rates of artificial bat roosts?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Multiple studies have identified key design and placement factors that influence artificial bat roost occupancy rates. Design factors include: bats prefer black bat boxes over grey, white, or wooden boxes (1024); concrete boxes have higher occupancy than wooden ones (1024); larger bat boxes show higher occupancy rates (1024); boxes with multiple compartments are preferred during breeding season (1024); and different species show preferences for different box designs (1024). Position factors include: orientation and sunlight exposure significantly affect occupancy, with some studies finding preferences for certain orientations (1024); height affects occupancy in some locations (1024); bat boxes on buildings have higher occupancy than those on trees (1024); and boxes are more likely to be occupied when installed in areas where bats previously roosted (1024). Temperature management is also important, with studies showing more bats in artificial roosts after modifications to reduce internal temperatures (2052) and heated boxes generally having lower occupancy rates (2052). Habitat placement matters, with higher occupancy in farm forestry sites compared to native forest (1024) and in forest fragments compared to pasture (1024).

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of different lighting modifications, such as using specific colors or filters, on bat activity?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The documents show that lighting modifications can have significant effects on bat activity. One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the UK (action 1020) found that hedges lit with ultraviolet filtered lights had higher soprano pipistrelle activity compared to hedges lit with unfiltered light, though no difference was found for common pipistrelles.

Regarding colored lighting, three studies evaluated red lighting effects on bats (action 2021). One replicated, controlled, site comparison study in the Netherlands found that red lighting resulted in higher activity for one of three bat species groups compared to white or green lighting. Another site comparison study in the Netherlands found that culverts illuminated with red light had similar activity of commuting Daubenton's bats as culverts illuminated with white or green light. Additionally, one replicated, controlled study in the UK found that more soprano pipistrelles emerged from a roost when lit with red light than when lit with white light, but no difference was found between red and blue lights.

However, no studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of using 'warm white' LED lights compared to 'cool' LED lights on bat populations (action 2020), or the effects of using low-level ultraviolet light to deter bats from turbines (action 1958).

question_details.query: As an alternative to providing bat boxes, what actions can improve subterranean roosting sites for bats in environments like mines or caves?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Actions that can improve subterranean roosting sites for bats include installing and maintaining cave gates (Action ID: 999) or mine gates (Action ID: 1963) to restrict public access, which has been shown to result in more or similar numbers of bats in caves after installation. Restricting artificial lighting in caves and around cave entrances (Action ID: 1994) can reduce bat flight activity, with studies showing that low intensity white lights or red lights result in fewer bat flights than full white lighting. Creating artificial caves or hibernacula (Action ID: 2049) has been implemented, with studies finding that artificial hibernacula were used by up to four bat species and that the number of bats using an artificial hibernaculum increased over nine years after construction. However, no studies were found evaluating the effects of providing artificial subterranean bat roosts to replace roosts in reclaimed mines (Action ID: 974) or disturbed caves (Action ID: 1005), or retaining bat access points to caves (Action ID: 1990).

question_details.query: What conservation actions can be implemented to mitigate the impacts of mining operations on bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One study found that maintaining the microclimate in closed/abandoned mines can be effective - modifying the microclimate by closing a man-made entrance resulted in a greater number of bats hibernating within the mine (Action ID: 1964). Installing and maintaining gates at mine entrances to restrict public access has been extensively studied across nine studies in the USA and Australia. The evidence shows mixed results: fewer bat species and fewer bats overall were found in mines after gates were installed, though some locations maintained stable or increased bat activity. Bat behavior was affected, with bats circling more and entering mines less after gates were installed, and up to 7% of bats collided with gates (Action ID: 1963). Other proposed conservation actions include excluding bats from roosts prior to mine reclamation (Action ID: 1961), providing artificial subterranean bat roosts to replace roosts in reclaimed mines (Action ID: 974), relocating bats from reclaimed mines to alternative subterranean roost sites (Action ID: 975), reopening entrances to closed mines and making them suitable for roosting bats (Action ID: 1965), and retaining access points for bats following mine closures (Action ID: 1962). However, no studies have yet evaluated the effectiveness of these actions.
summary_statements: Maintaining the microclimate in closed or abandoned mines can be an effective conservation action for bats.
Modifying the microclimate by closing a man-made entrance resulted in a greater number of bats hibernating within the mine.
Installing and maintaining gates at mine entrances to restrict public access has been extensively studied across nine studies in the USA and Australia.

Bat behavior was affected by the installation of gates at mine entrances.
Bats were observed circling more and entering mines less after gates were installed.
Up to 7% of bats collided with installed gates at mine entrances.
One proposed conservation action is to exclude bats from roosts prior to mine reclamation.
Another proposed conservation action is providing artificial subterranean bat roosts to replace roosts in reclaimed mines.
Relocating bats from reclaimed mines to alternative subterranean roost sites is a proposed conservation action.
